name: NPR
text:
Sen. James Lankford says one concern is tied to the 9/11 Commission, which said a lack of cooperation during the 2000 transition may have hurt preparations that could've thwarted the attack.

"This was...an issue of saying let's learn the lesson of 2000." https://t.co/PkkUU8qqxt

name: NPR
text:
The pandemic has upended many aspects of domestic life.

That's brought new attention to one of the most enduring disparities between men and women: the wide difference in handling housework and child care.
https://t.co/mwfx1QmDBa

name: NPR
text:
A new HIV prevention technique has proven remarkably effective at protecting women against the virus.

A new study finds a single injection of a drug called cabotegravir given every two months was more effective than a daily oral dose of Truvada.
https://t.co/KBIBOBmQp4

name: NPR
text:
Around 11 million Americans experienced "catastrophic medical expenses" — a term that refers to spending over 40% of income on health care after food and housing costs — in 2017, a study finds.

Privately insured people represented more than half of those. https://t.co/QwvpC2DbGS

name: NPR
text:
There is "no evidence" the Nov. 3 election was compromised, top U.S. cybersecurity officials have affirmed — calling it "the most secure in American history."
https://t.co/Q1SC9gaQCy

name: NPR
text: RT @lindaholmes: ICYMI: I pulled together the holiday movies coming this year so you know which have moppets, which have music, and which involve adorable small towns. https://t.co/ga7oSEsMJp

name: NPR
text:
A Justice Dept. report found that former Labor Secretary Alex Acosta used "poor judgment" in crafting a 2008 nonprosecution deal for Jeffrey Epstein — but did not commit professional misconduct.
https://t.co/AqpGjpNnuM

name: NPR
text:
Artist Kyungmi Shin was born in South Korea and emigrated to the U.S. at 19.

Her works show — in exquisite and haunting ways — the residues of colonialism, clashes of cultures, and the fact that our stories may change, but our histories stay with us.
https://t.co/yyLsQSfIFe

name: NPR
text:
"Among Us" — a social deduction game where you play a group of little space sausages trying to uncover the murderous imposters among you — originally came out in 2018.

But it's having a real moment in 2020.
https://t.co/S8LuV9deb1

name: NPR
text:
The pandemic is ravaging America's jails and prisons.

More than 1,300 inmates and prison staff have died from from the virus, according to a UCLA study. 

"It shows that the government is failing to protect the most vulnerable people," one attorney said.
https://t.co/OSd0e8MmMG

name: NPR
text:
Former President Obama's new memoir, "A Promised Land," covers his rise through the second year of his presidency — and doesn't spare readers the controversies that studded those years.
https://t.co/1zXY4jXqsD

name: NPR
text:
When Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, starts this weekend, fireworks will send smoke into already polluted skies — raising concerns about the impact of air pollution on coronavirus cases.
https://t.co/i33nQ7T5Jc

name: NPR
text:
Here's a roundup of the holiday films coming to cable and streaming this season — complete with notes to help you find the ones right up your alley. 
https://t.co/z69UYRcMTO

name: NPR
text:
For years, Malian musicians have urged the country to stay united and stand for peace. Now, their voices are again at the forefront — amid the chaos of both the coronavirus pandemic and civil strife.
https://t.co/9k2YFPlmff

name: NPR
text:
UPS will now allow drivers to grow beards after years of strict rules on personal appearance.
https://t.co/ZVtorAjrlF

name: NPR
text: It's fine. This is fine. Today's going to be just fine. https://t.co/B8SzD649qx

name: NPR
text: "We respect the choice of the American people," a foreign ministry spokesman said in China's first nod toward the end of the 2020 election. "We congratulate Mr. Biden and Ms. Harris. At the same time, the result will be confirmed according to U.S. laws." https://t.co/9ohyz5x6o3

name: NPR
text: Groups representing young progressives are calling on Biden to give progressives key cabinet posts, and to create a White House office to coordinate efforts to fight climate change. "Day 1, great, bring back all the Obama stuff. Day 2? Time to be bold." https://t.co/nz6Bb2kZEV

name: NPR
text: Tesla executive Elon Musk announced on Twitter that he'd taken four rapid coronavirus tests, with half coming back positive. Musk, who's expressed skepticism about the threat of the pandemic, is waiting for the result of a more accurate test. https://t.co/6MebUVXTth

name: NPR
text: President Trump signed an order in August demanding TikTok's owner sell the app to an American company by Thursday. But court rulings made the order virtually unenforceable, and the short-video platform continues to be available in the U.S. https://t.co/OCqT8ukRGh

name: NPR
text:
The votes from election 2020 are still being counted. Once that's done, there are several more official steps that come before a Biden inauguration. 

Here's a timeline from today to Jan. 20: https://t.co/0LGrtOJGhb

name: NPR
text:
RT @vacovino: New vid game consoles are out this week, if ya haven’t heard. Listen to @plante and @elisefavis tell you so on my latest for @NPR. 

https://t.co/gRodQuUJVn

name: NPR
text: RT @WPR: Moving away from home can be an exciting adventure for some people. For others, it can be a lonely journey. Writer and Wisconsin native June Melby reflects with @wisconsinlife on moving west and how a vintage jacket helped her feel a little less homesick. https://t.co/Ve7NPOpKlV

name: NPR
text: Coronavirus appears to be transferring between animals and workers at Greek mink farms, officials say, leading to at least 10 infections. But the strain hasn't mutated, as it has in mink in Denmark. https://t.co/I4Wk8t1hpq
